content.description:
The best problem here, this takes a direct line up the middle of the face on nice edges and plates to an easy mantle finish.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.

Grab a rounded hold at mid-height, run your feet up on smears and mantle the starting hold as you slap for the top.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location: Middle of the narrow south face.

content.description:
Carefully climb the right arete past some wafer thin edges and creaky jugs to an easy topout. Watch out for the yucca at the base.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.protection: pad, maybe a spotter to keep you off the yucca
content.location: Right side of the west face.

content.description:
Grab the slanting arete and rock up and onto the lip then finish up easy slab to the top.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.

Edges (some dubious), with a little button for your foot at the start, lead up the face to the arete which is folowed to the top. Watch out for the yucca at the base.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.protection: pad, maybe a spotter to keep you out of the yucca
content.location: Left side of the west face.
